entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 26th December 2021 - Boxing Day

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 26th December 2021 - Boxing Day
media:group.media:description:
Welcome to our Boxing Day service. You can use the links below to skip to other parts of the service
00:00 - Music before worship and photos
18:04 - Welcome and Prayer
19:09 - Carol - Infant holy Engage worship
21:32 - Introduction… ….One boxing day a couple of years ago, I shut down the computer, ignored all my unread books and set up a lego railway set in the study – this was the result
23:02 - ….One of the carols linked to today is Good King Wenceslas – which takes up that theme of compassion and service. It’s a great carol to sing outside on a frosty day. It ends with the words Therefore, Christian folk, be sure Wealth or rank possessing You who now will bless the poor Shall yourselves find blessing. 26:31 - Carol - Good King Wenceslas (Official Music Video)
29:14 - Intro to reading
32:09 - Reading: Colossians 3:12-17 The Message
33:36 - Prayer Lord’s Prayer 36:44 - 37:11 - Blessing
37:15 - Hymn - From heaven you came 42:03 - Carols from the RGS Carol Concert - Choir and Brass Ensemble from All Saints Church, recorded on 14th December 2020. https://www.rgshw.com/news/?pid=3&nid=1&storyid=228 with grateful thanks 42:03 - Once in Royal David’s City 46:49 - Hark! The Herald Angels Sing 50:12 - O Come, All Ye Faithful 53:38 - O Little Town of Bethlehem 56:47 - Unto us is Born a Son
#JoyToTheWorld #BoxingDay #OneCanTrust #WycombeHomelessConnection #RGSHW #Christmas #Lego #SwitchOffTheTV https://onecantrust.org.uk/ https://twitter.com/rgshw

entry.title: Morning Worship - Saturday 25th December 2021 - Christmas Day

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Saturday 25th December 2021 - Christmas Day
media:group.media:description:
Welcome to our Christmas Day service. You can use the links below to skip to other parts of the service
00:00 - Music before worship and photos
18:04 - Welcome / Introduction
19:45 - Hymn - O come all ye faithful Engage Worship Video
23:10 - Advent candles (film of Cores End)
23:52 - Prayer
Intro of video Unto us produced Christian Vision). It’s a modern-day account of the nativity, filmed and produced to be like a contemporary TV drama. And after that we’ll hear the story from Luke’s Gospel – read by the Sparks family
26:02 - Video Unto Us
30:38 - 32:43 - Reading Luke 2. 1 – 20
32:49 - Hymn - Once in Royal Engage worship Video
36:51 - Prayers Lord’s Prayer
40:16 - 40:44 - Blessing
41:05 - Song - On Christmas Day Engage worship
45:50 - Carols from the RGS Carol Concert - Choir and Brass Ensemble from All Saints Church, recorded on 14th December 2020. https://www.rgshw.com/news/?pid=3&nid=1&storyid=228 with grateful thanks 45:50 - Once in Royal David’s City 53:58 - Hark! The Herald Angels Sing 53:59 - O Come, All Ye Faithful 57:15 - O Little Town of Bethlehem 01:00:33 - Unto us is Born a Son
#Christmas #JoyToTheWorld #OneCanTrust #RGSHW #SwitchOffTheTV #OpeningPresents #WycombeHomelessConnection
https://twitter.com/rgshw https://onecantrust.org.uk/

entry.title: Worship - Sunday, 19th December 2021 - Carols with Candlelight

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Worship - Sunday, 19th December 2021 - Carols with Candlelight
media:group.media:description:
00.00 Photos and music before service
Welcome given by a church elder, Angus Massie
Call to worship led by the minister, Terry Hinks
Carol: O come all ye faithful [on screen or R&S 160 vs 1-5]
Lighting of the Advent Candles
Song: Christ our light (Tune: Frere Jacques unaccompanied) Christ our light, Christ our light, light our lives. We’ll be lights to others. Light our lives. Prayer
1 st Bible Reading: Isaiah 40: 1 – 5 and 9 Ian Bogart
Carol: It came upon a midnight clear [on screen or R&S 144]
2 nd Bible Reading: Luke 1: 26 – 38 Norma Garden
Worship Song ‘Adore’ by Chris Tomlin (video)
3 rd Bible Reading: Luke 2: 1–7 (Good News) Zion Ogbewe
Carol: See him lying on a bed of straw [on screen or R&S 151] led by Worship Group
Reading: ‘Mary looks into the eyes of Jesus’ Lesley Bogart
Carol: Silent night [on screen or R&S 147] Reading: ‘Silent night’ Elaysa Ogbewe
4 th Bible Reading: Luke 2: 8 – 20 Alan Yates
Reflection: ‘changed lives’
Worship Song ‘Emmanuel’ [on screen]
5 th Bible Reading: Matthew 2: 1 – 12 Richard Harding
Introducing our Christmas charity Embrace the Middle East (video)
Carol: In the bleak mid winter [on screen or R&S 162]
Reading: ‘Holy Child’ Abigail Lokko
Prayers of intercession Lord’s Prayer
All: Our Father, who art in heaven, hallowed be thy name; thy kingdom come; thy will be done; on earth as it is in heaven. Give us this day our daily bread. And forgive us our trespasses, as we forgive those who trespass against us. And lead us not into temptation; but deliver us from evil. For thine is the kingdom, the power, and the glory, for ever and ever. Amen.
Carol: Hark! the herald angels sing [on screen or R&S 159]
Minister: Blessing All say: Amen.
Please stand as the Bible is taken out of church Organ Voluntary: Organ Sonata No 1 - Alexandre Guilmant

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 12th December 2021
media:group.media:description:
00.00 Photos and music before service
07:55 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder) 09:33 - Call to worship With hearts changed by love, with lives shaped by grace, with relationships braced by integrity, and with the blessing of the Holy Spirit upon us, come as you are and as you hope to be to worship the Lord of Advent. Amen.
10:40 - Hymn R&S 134 On Jordan’s Banks the Baptist’s cry Tune: 537 Winchester new
13:00 - Opening Prayers
16:15 - Theme Introduction Joy - not much of it around at the moment? What might we be joyful about? Printer paper being available It's warmer The fact we can still gather in person A great view on a run Thinking about what we can do to make others happy Sharing a meal Listening
21:05 - 21:45 - Prayer
21:47 - Lighting three candles on Advent crown
Let all who take refuge in God rejoice; let them ever sing for joy.
The candles are lit. Jesus is the light of the world. A light no darkness can ever put out. Will we be able to celebrate with our families this Christmas
23:10 - Song R&S 522 From heaven you came, helpless babe
28:26 - 29:27 - Reading: Philippians 4.4-7 read by Aurelia Awuku
4 Rejoice in the Lord always. I will say it again: rejoice! 5 Let your gentleness be evident to all. The Lord is near. 6 Do not be anxious about anything, but in every situation, by prayer and petition, with thanksgiving, present your requests to God. 7 And the peace of God, which transcends all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.
30:15 - Song R&S 286 Rejoice in the Lord always (as a round)
33:26 - 36:01 - Reading: Luke 3.7-18 read by Alan Yates
7 John said to the crowds coming out to be baptised by him, ‘You brood of vipers! Who warned you to flee from the coming wrath? 8 Produce fruit in keeping with repentance. And do not begin to say to yourselves, “We have Abraham as our father.” For I tell you that out of these stones God can raise up children for Abraham. 9 The axe has been laid to the root of the trees, and every tree that does not produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire.’ 10 ‘What should we do then?’ the crowd asked. 11 John answered, ‘Anyone who has two shirts should share with the one who has none, and anyone who has food should do the same.’ 12 Even tax collectors came to be baptised. ‘Teacher,’ they asked, ‘what should we do?’ 13 ‘Don’t collect any more than you are required to,’ he told them. 14 Then some soldiers asked him, ‘And what should we do?’
He replied, ‘Don’t extort money and don’t accuse people falsely – be content with your pay.’ 15 The people were waiting expectantly and were all wondering in their hearts if John might possibly be the Messiah. 16 John answered them all, ‘I baptise you with[b] water. But one who is more powerful than I will come, the straps of whose sandals I am not worthy to untie. He will baptise you with[c] the Holy Spirit and fire. 17 His winnowing fork is in his hand to clear his threshing-floor and to gather the wheat into his barn, but he will burn up the chaff with unquenchable fire.’ 18 And with many other words John exhorted the people and proclaimed the good news to them.
37:07 - Hymn R&S 200 The kingdom of God Tune: (ii) Out Skerries
38:47 - 56:50 - Sermon What then should we do? Here we are this morning hopefully alive and well. Recent news of the meteor the size of the Eiffel tower skimming past the earth Context is important though as it passed 2.4 million miles away The gospel reading leaves us with an image of the sandwich board stating "The end is nigh" If that's good news, what does bad news look like Repentance is the foundation of the new kingdom He who is faithful and just will forgive us of our sins Repentance is about building a better world Government parties around Christmas 2020 whilst the rest of the country was under restrictions Saying sorry and resigning does show a level of repentance When we get it wrong we need to hold up our hands and say sorry Just saying sorry isn't the same as repentance "Turn around where possible" from our sat-nav when we make a mistake
56:52 - Hymn MP 806 Beauty for brokenness
01:03:04 - Prayers of Intercession Closing Prayers
01:08:43 - Hymn R&S 574 Go forth and tell Tune: 740 Woodlands
01:11:30 - 01:12:09 - Blessing
01:12:40 - 01:15:30 - Organ voluntary

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 5th December 2021
media:group.media:description:
00.00 Photos and music before service
07:30 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle
09:33 - Call to worship Minister: In our watching and waiting: All: Come, Lord Jesus. Minister: In our hopes and fears: All: Come, Lord Jesus. Minister: In our stillness and worship: All: Come, Lord Jesus. Minister: Come, Lord Jesus, bless and surprise us as we look forward to the celebration of your birth.
10:00 - Hymn 141 Make way, make way
13:06 - Opening Prayers
15:45 18:45 - Introduction: ‘Clear the way’ When cars were first introduced in this country, red flags were required to be carried in advance to clear the way and make sure all was safe Clearing the way is a theme in Advent thinking about John the Baptist clearing the way for Jesus John was a strange challenging figure Looking at my bookshelf makes me thing I could do with clearing it somewhat When they introduce John, the gospel writers use words from Isaiah
18:55 - Lighting two candles on Advent crown Reader: We light our first candle, as a sign of our hope in Jesus Christ. And we light the second candle to give thanks for the Bible that is a light to guide and inspire us:
All: God of hope, come to us again this Advent. May your Word be a lamp to our feet and a light on our path. Amen.
20:17 - Song MP 1086 Light of the world
23:03 - Introduction to the reading Who knows where Malachi actually is in the bible? It only appears once in the 3 year Malachi was the last of the 12 minor prophets and the last book in the old testament. From about 450 years before the birth of Christ Malachi may not be the name of the writer of this book, "malachi" means messenger The original words were arranged on a scroll by the ancient editor and as the words were a message, it's thought this led to the nickname At his time he was exhorting people to change their ways, warning them of the judgement to come.
25:19 - 26:29 - Reading: Malachi 3. 1-4 NIVUK 3 ‘I will send my messenger, who will prepare the way before me. Then suddenly the Lord you are seeking will come to his temple; the messenger of the covenant, whom you desire, will come,’ says the LORD Almighty. 2 But who can endure the day of his coming? Who can stand when he appears? For he will be like a refiner’s fire or a launderer’s soap. 3 He will sit as a refiner and purifier of silver; he will purify the Levites and refine them like gold and silver. Then the LORD will have men who will bring offerings in righteousness, 4 and the offerings of Judah and Jerusalem will be acceptable to the LORD, as in days gone by, as in former years.
Music for reflection (Be still for the presence of the Lord)
27:45 - 31:17 - Reading: Luke 3.1-6 NIVUK read by Olive Shepherd (seated) 3 In the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar – when Pontius Pilate was governor of Judea, Herod tetrarch of Galilee, his brother Philip tetrarch of Iturea and Traconitis, and Lysanias tetrarch of Abilene – 2 during the high-priesthood of Annas and Caiaphas, the word of God came to John son of Zechariah in the wilderness. 3 He went into all the country around the Jordan, preaching a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins. 4 As it is written in the book of the words of Isaiah the prophet: ‘A voice of one calling in the wilderness, “Prepare the way for the Lord, make straight paths for him. 5 Every valley shall be filled in, every mountain and hill made low. The crooked roads shall become straight, the rough ways smooth.
6 And all people will see God’s salvation.
31:25 - Hymn 137 Hark the glad sound
34:06 - Prayer 34:36 - 46:56 - Short Address Are we prepared to be surprised this Advent season? Ready to find God at work where we thought he was absent, to find him in unexpected places Luke tells us to expect the unexpected The reading starts with the messy world of politics and power Luke reminds his readers who is in power When he introduces John the Baptiser he also tells us who is in power It's this messy, conflict ridden world that God sends his message into So here we have a world of power, conflict and tension We are then shifted to the wilderness, a place with no rules God's power is very different to human power and authority It brings transformation, hope and new beginnings
46:57 - 48:28 - Prayer 48:52 - Prayers for others
53:35 - Hymn MP 1201 Longing for light
58:10 Offering of bread and wine and Offering Prayer We invite you to share in the bread and wine at church (or at home) united in the name of Christ. Thanksgiving Prayer and Lord’s Prayer Distribution of bread and wine (Music during distribution) Closing Prayers
01:07:28 - Hymn 740 - Tell out my soul
01:10:37 - 01:10:57 - Blessing
01:11:44 - 01:15:03 - Organ Voluntary

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship, Sunday, 28th November 2021
media:group.media:description:
00.00 Photos and music before service
09:35 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (elder) 10:35 - Introduction and Call to worship
11:23 - Hymn - O Come, O Come Emmanuel
18:16 - Opening Prayers and Lord’s Prayer
20:27 - Introducing theme: Faithful One
23:52 - Song - At The Name of Jesus
26:57 - Lighting of the first advent candle 27:42 - Advent song - Like a candle flame
28:49 - Introduction to Bible readings
31:07 - Reading - Psalm 25:1-10 33:00 - Reading - Luke 21:25-36
34:43 - Hymn - Lo He Comes With Clouds Descending
39:55 - 51:42 - Address An address in two parts: 1) An update on Wycombe Youth for Christ, 2) Reflections on the readings God's impact in WYFC: Growing the team, outreach in schools, giving out hot chocolate, chance encounters, opportunities to help, detached youth work, sharing Jesus with young people. Relationships - bringing our concerns before God A man crying out to God David declaring his dependence on the Lord - an expression of trust "All the ways of the Lord are loving towards those who keep His covenants" This advent, will you join me in moving forward in hope, hope in what the Lord is doing here and now Praying that God will fill you with joy and hope
51:39 - Hymn - Come Thou Long Expected Jesus
54:06 - Offering prayer (acknowledging our gifts to God)
54:49 - Prayers of Intercession Leader: Lord, show us how to live ALL: And give us the courage to go forward in hope
58:27 - Hymn - Hail To The Lords Anointed
01:03:34 - 01:03:06 - Blessing
01:03:57 - 01:08:52 - Organ Voluntary

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship, Sunday, 21st November 2021
media:group.media:description:
00.00 Photos and music before service
11:45 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (elder)
12:46 - Introduction and Call to worship Psalm 93 v 1-5 The LORD reigns, he is robed in majesty; the LORD is robed in majesty and armed with strength; indeed, the world is established, firm and secure. Your throne was established long ago; you are from all eternity. The seas have lifted up, LORD, the seas have lifted up their voice; the seas have lifted up their pounding waves. Mightier than the thunder of the great waters, mightier than the breakers of the sea – the LORD on high is mighty. Your statutes, LORD, stand firm; holiness adorns your house for endless days
15:07 - Hymn MP13 All hail the power of Jesus name
18:01 - Opening prayers and the Lord’s prayer
21:21 - Reading Revelation Ch 1 vv 4b – 8
23:05 - 25:45 - Introduction to theme of the service What if I told you that on this piece of paper I had every word in the bible, every word ever spoken? God is like an A-Z, the beginning and end of everything God has always been God is at this very moment now God will always be forever God's kingdom is wherever Jesus reigns in our hearts
25:59 - Hymn MP 207 Hallelujah sing to Jesus
29:52 - 30:48 - Reading John18 vv 33b – 37
Young people leave for their group
31:44 - Hymn R&S 638 Thy kingdom come o God
34:25 - 48:13 - Address Here we are at the end of another Christian church year Next week is the start of advent Today is when we remember Christ the King This festival is not an ancient one in the calendar Only established in 1925 by Pope Pious the 11th when Europe was in chaos, inflation was rampant and the seeds of the forthcoming disaster were being sowed The conversation from John's reading allows John to pronounce that Jesus is a king with divine authority Too often truth is often what power says it is Jesus defied logic by the way he lived and taught Teaching that truth is the cornerstone of a decent society
48:21 - Hymn R&S 522 From heaven you came helpless babe
52:46 - Prayers of intercession
56:33 - Hymn R&S 262 Crown him with many crowns
01:00:02 - 01:00:20 - Blessing 01:00:45 - 01:05:18 - Organ voluntary

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship, Sunday, 14th November 2021
media:group.media:description:
00.00 Photos and music before service
14:45 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (Sue)
11:54 - Introduction and Call to worship Psalm 33 v 2-5
13:04 - Hymn - God is Love, let heaven adore Him
16:50 - Opening Prayers and Lord’s Prayer
20:08 - 25:49 - Introductory Talk – “Dark and Light”
What was special about Sunday, 31st October, 2 weeks ago A 25 hour day - what did you do with the additional hour? Darker earlier in the day Different shades of light and dark Close your eyes and cover them to experience the darkness Remembering the dark times of war
Being able to meet family again
25:50 - Song - The Lord’s my Shepherd led by the worship band
Blessing as Junior Church depart
30:18 - Act of Remembrance
32:15 - Prayers for peace (using R&S 641 – We pray for peace)
37:46 - Last Post Video
39:00 - Two minutes silence
41:34 - 42:05 - Poem: “They shall not grow old …”
42:38 - 45:52 - Readings: Mark 13 v1-8; Hebrews10 11-25
46:18 - Prayer 47:30 - 01:00:18 - Sermon – “Promises, promises!” The gospel reading talks about war. It follows on from Jesus' triumphant entry into Jerusalem but we know it comes before the darkest of dark times when Jesus was crucified The disciples comment to Jesus about how magnificent the temple stones were. 12m long, 4m deep and 6m high, huge pieces of stone that look as if they will be there for ever Jesus disabuses the disciples of this saying the stones will collapse and every stone will be thrown down. A shock to the disciples Jesus is anticipating the destruction of Jerusalem in AD70 Jesus gives the disciples some of the signs of the end of the age Jesus makes it clear that they should not worry but to watch and be prepared. Promises made and promises kept? Do our politicians keep their promises? COP26 in Glasgow, what promises have been made and which will be kept Greta Thunberg and "Blah, blah, blah"
01:00:31 - Hymn - Rejoice the Lord is King
01:04:03 - 01:09:13 - Offering Prayer & Prayers for Others
01:09:21 - Closing Hymn - All I once held dear
01:12:44 - 01:13:03 - Blessing
01:13:26 - 01:16:50 - Organ voluntary

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship, Sunday, 7th November 2021
media:group.media:description:
00:00 Introductory photos and notices
09:24 - Welcome, introduction and call to worship (from Psalm 146.1-5)
09:58 - Lighting of the peace candle 10:40 - Call to worship
Praise the LORD, my soul. I will praise the LORD all my life; I will sing praise to my God as long as I live. Blessed are those whose help is the God of Jacob, whose hope is in the LORD their God. The Lord is the Maker of heaven and earth, the sea, and everything in them – God remains faithful for ever.
11:30 - Hymn For all the saints
15:18 - Opening Prayer of adoration and confession
17:19 - 23:43 - Introduction: ‘Not to be forgotten’
A glorious autumn day, the leaves are falling but taking their time A month of remembering Remembering and forgetting Every piece matters A community of faith A challenge - remembering the people who feel forgotten Those who died in conflict The planet on which we depend No-one if forgotten by God The ribbons from the gate to remember loved ones
23:49 - HYMN R&S 549 One more step along the world
26:50 - 32:55 - Introducing the readings, stories of two widows
Reading 1 Kings 17:8-16 (NIVUK) Reading: Psalm 146. 6 – 10 Reading: Mark 12:38-44 (NIVUK)
33:04 - Song - In my life, Lord
35:05 - 49:14 - Short Address We have seen weighty discussions this week about the climate crisis Stepping back from the big things to the small ones Small things can challenge the big and powerful interests - Greta Thunberg Small is beautiful by E. F. Schumacher - humane economics appropriate to the situation. Ecomonics for the people who matter
Our readings focus on small things The widow's generosity keeps flowing Hope for all Jesus had an eye for small things too
Praying the voices of the smallest nations will be heard in Glasgow
49:35 - Prayer
50:50 - Hymn - I come with joy to meet my Lord
53:54 - Offering of bread and wine and Offering Prayer We invite you to share in the bread and wine at church (or at home) united in the name of Christ.
Thanksgiving Prayer and Lord’s Prayer
Distribution of bread and wine (Music during distribution)
01:02:25 - Closing Prayers
01:04:20 - HYMN R&S 21 Praise God from whom all blessings flow
01:05:15 - 01:05:38 - Blessing 01:06:05 - 01:10:45 - Organ voluntary
Refreshments are being served after church (in the Meeting Place – please bring it back into church to drink). Do stay if you can.

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship, Sunday, 31st October 2021
media:group.media:description:
00:00 Introductory photos and notices
Worship led by Terry Hinks Organist: Graham Nash
09:45 - Welcome, introduction and call to worship
10:16 - Lighting of the peace candle
11:38 - Hymn - All people that on earth do dwell
14:44 - Opening Prayer of adoration and confession with the response With all creation We praise you, Loving God. Lord’s Prayer
18:01 - Thinking of those whose lives are challenging in Eastern Europe 19:03 - Shoebox collection – Daphne Stopworth 1 million shoeboxes distributed since the start of Link to Hope in 1992, 20,000 in 2020 Donations of money as well as items in shoeboxes
25:04 - Prayer 25:57 - 28:22 - One World Week – act now for our children’s world
28:29 - Song - Let there be love shared among us
30:35 - Introducing the readings
31:17 - Reading: Deuteronomy 6.1-9 (NIVUK) read by Jeany Bien
33:22 - Psalm 148 read by minister and congregation
35:34 - 37:00 - Reading: Mark 12.28-34 (NIVUK) read by Fiona Warden
37:15 - Song - Such love
39:55 - 55:57 - Address Today we have heard familiar readings They are familiar but stretch our minds and hearts Deuteronomy covers how people will live with God, facing both triumph and disaster yet still go forward Moses says the commandments are to be part of daily life Stretch your mind across the amazing universe which we are discovering more about but still have so much to find; across this planet with all the diverse species Have you come to worship this morning feeling nothing of God's presence? We can offer worship all the same We cannot do it on our own, we need the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ
55:58 - Music for reflection
57:22 - Offering Prayer (gifts are brought forward)
57:59 - Hymn - Day by day dear Lord (sung seated as a prayer)
59:41 - Prayers for the world
01:06:14 - Hymn Love divine all loves excelling
01:09:58 - 01:10:20 - Blessing
01:10:45 - 01:14:54 - Organ voluntary
Refreshments are being served after church (in the Meeting Place – please bring it back into church to drink). Do stay if you can.

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship, Sunday, 24th October 2021
media:group.media:description:
00:00 Introductory photos and notices
Worship led by Steve Burton Organist: Charles Brewster
11:10 - Welcome 11:35 - Lighting of the peace candle
12:12 - Call to worship 13:25 - Hymn - To the name of our salvation 17:30 - Prayers of adoration and confession 20:37 - 23:32 - Talk - The reading from Mark and Bartimaeus How would we deal with losing our sight? Listening to Nunc Dimitus The more I heard the music, the thought of not hearing felt worse than not being able to see Close your eyes for a few moments and imagine you are blind How will you survive, how will you work, how will you move around. 23:45 - Song - Jesus, Hope of the nations 28:23 - 30:08 - Reading - Mark 10, 46-52 30:20 - Hymn - A Glorious Company We Sing 32:30 - 47:50 - Address Lines from the reading from Mark The striking contrast in the reading, a great multitude and a lone individual It is impressive to see Jesus turn his attention from the crowd to the one. There is evidence of something deeper than just being aware of surroundings This narrative comes with pertinence for a generation that acts on multitudes and quantities The lowest in society can too easily get lost What does our manner say about us Are we like the crowd or Jesus?
48:00 - Hymn - Lord of light whose name outshineth 52:14 - Prayers of intercession 55:11 - HYMN - God is love let heaven adore Him 59:11 - 59:32 - Blessing 59:53 - 01:03:18 - Organ voluntary
Refreshments are being served after church (in the Meeting Place – please bring it back into church to drink). Do stay if you can.

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship, Sunday, 17th October 2021
media:group.media:description:
00:00 Introductory photos and notices
SIGHT LOSS SUNDAY Worship led by Sue Thorne Organist: Charles Brewster
14:40 - Welcome 15:01 - Lighting of peace candle
15:27 - Introduction and Call to worship led by Sue Thorne
16:45 - Hymn MP 1201 Longing for Light, We wait in the Darkness (Christ be our Light)
20:54 - Opening Prayers and Lord’s Prayer
23:07 - Introducing theme: Sight Loss Sunday
25:45 - 28:10 - A recorded message from David Reynolds Sight loss Sunday is the day we try to understand sight loss and those people suffering from it. The impact of COVID on those with sight loss We are not a minority that shouts from the rooftops Can we examine the attitudes to people with disabilities Hope that we will gain a greater understanding of people with sight loss within the church
28:11 - Song MP 1008 The Lord’s my Shepherd (Townend)
30:09 - Introduction to Bible readings
Readings 2 Kings 6:8-22 NIVUK read by Kate Yates Mark 10 46-52 NIVUK read by Alan Yates
35:20 - Song R&S 522 From Heaven you came (Servant King)
39:30 - 50:09 - A recorded reflection by Dr Mike Townsend (Torch Trust) Sight loss and sight from a Christian point of view Sight loss and spiritual sight Sight is not just on and off, it's variable Elisha found in Syria and the army being struck with sight loss
50:16 - Offering prayer (acknowledging our gifts to God) and prayers for the world
53:35 - Hymn R&S 117 How Great Thou Art
58:27 - 58:37 - Blessing
58:55 - Organ voluntary
There is a basket in the entrance for gifts of money and a box for donations to One Can Foodbank.
HOW TO GIVE Donations can be left in the collection basket at the back of church. We are grateful for people’s regular giving and donations. If you would like to give to the church by Standing Order, bank transfer or cheque please contact the treasurer: Sue Thorne (Trinity) suethorne24@btinternet.com 01494 564635
Refreshments are being served after church (in the Meeting Place – please bring it back into church to drink). Do stay if you can.
Sight Loss Sunday is a new initiative from Torch Trust. It has two main purposes: • To raise awareness of the prevalence of sight loss in church and local community. • To encourage Christians to nurture the unique gifts, talents and abilities that people with sight loss can bring to church life. Torch Trust believes that all people with sight loss have a valuable part to play in churches and Christian communities, and Sight Loss Sunday is designed to equip us to live out these values in our own congregation. Founded in 1959, Torch Trust offers Christian products and services to improve the lives of people with sight loss. They offer Bibles, hymn books and a whole variety of publications in a range of accessible formats including braille, large print and audio. They contribute to RNIB Connect Radio with "Reflections" which airs on a Sunday morning. They also offer a range of bespoke Christian holidays for people with sight loss. Their "Sight Loss Friendly Church" initiative offers training, support and advice to churches of all denominations who wish to be more inclusive of people with sight loss. They provide regular training sessions and catch-up sessions online.
Both Trinity and Cores End Churches are registered as Sight Loss Friendly Churches and we want to do everything we can to include all people, whatever their abilities, in the life and work of the church. For more information please speak to Sue after the service or visit the Torch Trust website: www.sightlossfriendlychurch.org.uk

entry.title: Morning Service from Trinity & Cores End URC's 10th Jan 2021

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Service from Trinity & Cores End URC's 10th Jan 2021
media:group.media:description:
00:00 - Music and notices before worship
15:49 - Welcome 17:24 - Prayers for peace in our world and lighting of the peace candle 18:45 - Song - God of Glory 21:24 - 22:28 - Prayers 22:36 - Talk - What does beginning mean to you What new beginnings have you made? Life is not easy at the moment Not easy for children finally being back in school Not easy for people with medical needs delayed Life is for new beginnings Are you beginning anything new at the moment - a new book, puzzle or TV series Beginnings in the world of nature - snowdrops and daffodils Last week in the Church calendar we move from Christmas to epiphany. Today we focus on the baptism of Jesus 26:06 - 27:15 - Reading Genesis Ch1 vv1-5 27:20 - Song - As the sun rises on a new day 31:58 - Meditation Some of you will have been doing jigsaws over the Christmas period A meditation on a jigsaw puzzle to reflect on our own lives and how the jumble of pieces is brought together 34:44 - Prayer 35:19 - Talk The picture of Christ knowing he is loved by God and pleasing to him 35:47 - Reading - Mark 1, 1-11 38:17 - 50:11 - Talk The news this week has been increasingly grim: Spiralling COVID numbers, schools closed a day after opening, a new lockdown, events in America. We won't want to see another week like that any time soon There may be hope behind the headlines - the vaccination programme increasing, education continuing, American democracy has survived Our reading is all about new beginnings In just 11 verses, Mark takes to the declaration of Jesus as the son of God. Nothing about the birth, his focus is the baptism where Jesus begins his ministry and "goes public" Three aspects of that baptism: Jesus was baptised alongside the crowd of ordinary people, Jesus was baptised by John, that great prophet of the old testament, and Jesus was baptised by the spirit.
50:15 - Prayers of intercession 54:17 - Song - Brother, Sister, Let Me Serve You 57:13 - 57:42 - Blessing 57:45 - Music and notices after the service

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship, Sunday, 10th October 2021
media:group.media:description:
00:00 - Music before the service
10:55 - Welcome, introduction and lighting of peace candle
13:07 - Call to worship (Psalm 100:1-5)
00:15:25 - Hymn - Majesty
18:37 - Prayers and Lord’s prayer
21:31 - 33:40 - Introducing the theme:
What is the YMCA Founded by George Williams, came from a farming family but was sent off to the nearest town to learn the cloth trade. Challenged by the long hours, low pay and lack of care in the workplace he felt the Lord had restored him and wanted him to help young men experience the benefits he had. 2 introductory videos. Why people become homeless, how the YMCA helps get them back on their feet, working with Wycombe Homeless Connection to be the next stage of the journey back to independence
33:43 - Song - All I once held dear MP799
37:07 - Introduction to Bible readings
Readings: Matthew 9:9 Matthew 25:31 – 40
Matthew 28:16 – 20 read by Sarah and Samuel Evans
40:35 - 01:03:26 - Address Thinking about "calling" What comes to mind when you think about being called? Batman? With the boy wonder Robin by his side A shining light in the sky alerting them to need Our political leaders have been setting out their stalls at the party conferences wanting people to heed their calls #BuildBackBetter #GettingOnWithTheJob Jesus' call is not like any of these, he is claiming to be the Messiah A simple message - "follow me". Not "because this or that", just "follow me" Jesus isn't like any earthly leader, dying and coming back to life , an eternal change Remember that Jesus himself was homeless, not nice lunch after the service. He needed the help and care of others to live, sleep and eat. Being called to love and serve others
01:03:28 - Hymn - I the Lord of sea and sky MP857
01:08:32 - Offering prayer (we offer all that has been given for God’s work this week) Prayers for the world
01:11:13 - Hymn Over all the earth MP1101
01:13:52 - 01:14:29 - Blessing
01:15:07 - 01:18:22 - Organ voluntary

entry.title: Morning Worship - 3rd January 2021 restarted service stream

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - 3rd January 2021 restarted service stream
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Welcome back
00:00:11 - Prayer of adoration and confession
02:19 - Introduction: Rise and shine! Have you taken down your Christmas decorations? Christmas is not just a one day feast Our knitted nativity scene is missing the shepherds but does have 3 strangers - the wise men Matthew's story of the wise men is what we will be looking at today Reminders of the stars made in the Junior Church service just before Christmas, the star guiding the Wise Men to find Jesus, a sign of hope in dark times
04:49 - Introduction to the readings 05:26 - 07:02 - Readings: Isaiah 60.1-6 NIVUK read by Alan Yates
07:05 - Song - Come all you people, come and praise your maker sung by TEC Singers
09:22 - Reading: Matthew 2: 1 – 12 11:34 - Short prayer 12:00 - 24:40 Short Address
2020 is dead and buried and some of us are thankful for that but its effect will remain with us for years to come 4 stories from the Church Times that define the past year Covid-19 Black Lives Matter Climate Change Safeguarding Matthew, the most Jewish of the gospels starts focusing on Gentiles 4 highlights from the story in Matthew
24:49 - Time for quiet reflection and prayer for the world
27:28 - Offering – please stand for the Prayer of Dedication Eternal God we come to you now to offer the praise of our lips and the service of our lives. We recommit ourselves to walk the way of Jesus, to seek your will for our lives and for our world. Unite us as one body in Christ, renew us by your Spirit, that we may be true channels of your love and peace, through Jesus Christ our Saviour and Friend. Amen.
29:10 - Song - Don’t be afraid Don't be afraid, my love is stronger, My love is stronger than your fear. Don't be afraid, my love is stronger, And I have promised to be always near John Bell Iona Community Don't Be Afraid - John Bell Iona Community music and video (musictory.com)
32:19 - Communion 37:54 - Closing Prayers
39:13 - Song - Lord of all hopefulness
41:48 - 42:11 - Blessing 42:20 - MUSIC AFTER WORSHIP / NOTICE SLIDES
